Award.AwardTitle: Probing Hopping Conduction in Long, Pi-Conjugated Molecular Wires Assembled by Click Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award sponsored by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF, Prof. Dan Frisbie of the University of Minnesota and his students aim to understand how pai-conjugated molecules conduct electricity. In particular, their goal is to connect pi-conjugated molecules between metal electrodes and to probe conduction in the "hopping regime" in which electrons are injected into the molecular orbitals and hop from site-to-site along the molecular backbone, driven by the potential difference between the metal contacts. Building and characterizing the conduction of these structures will allow a better understanding of how molecular architecture impacts electrical conductivity in molecules. It will also allow useful electronic functions (e.g. current rectification) to be built into the molecular wires, which may enable new nanoelectronic applications.

The experimental approach involves building pi-conjugated molecular wires from metal electrodes using sequential "click chemistry" reactions to connect monomers in a step-wise fashion. This chemistry allows the syntheses of molecular wires that are tens of nanometers in length with simultaneous control of the wire architecture on 1 nanometer length scales. Wires will be made with many different chemical functionalities, including redox-active sites, and with cascades of energy levels that can facilitate uni-directional electron transport (i.e., current rectification). After synthesis, the metal electrodes bearing oriented assemblies of wires will be inserted into an atomic force microscope (AFM), where the microscope probe tip will be brought into contact with the wire assembly with a controlled, nano-newton compressive load. In this manner, the AFM functions as an electrical probe station. Voltages applied between the metal AFM tip and the metal substrate drive current through the wires and the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of the wires will be measured. The I-V characteristics will be recorded as a function of molecular length, chemical functionality and temperature. Analysis of this information will be used to create a more complete understanding of structure-conduction relationships in conducting molecules.

The broader impacts of this proposal will be in the training of graduate students and undergraduates in important emerging areas of chemistry and nanoscience. In particular students will develop skills in molecular synthesis, structure characterization, atomic force microscopy, and electrical measurements. They will also develop a more complete physical understanding of the physical principles involved in electrical conduction in molecules and nanoelectronics, more generally. In addition, this grant will offer summer research opportunities for three high school students from the Twin Cities metropolitan area, exposing them to scientific research at an early stage and positively impacting their understanding of chemical concepts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored electrical conduction in nanoscopic molecular wires connected at either end to metal electrodes, as part of a broader effort in molecular electronics. Molecular electronics is an interdisciplinary field of nanoscience that aims to employ molecules in ultrasmall circuits. Development of molecular electronics requires a thorough understanding of how the structures of molecules and the metal-molecule contacts impact conduction, and this was a central focus of this project. So-called ‘click chemistry’ techniques were employed to sequentially build up a parallel assembly of molecules 1-10 nm in length from a metal substrate. This chemistry afforded nanometer level control over the architecture of the molecules in the direction perpendicular to the substrate. After synthesis of the molecules was complete, a second, spring-loaded metal contact was then made to the top of the molecules, as shown in the figure.  The advantage of the spring-loaded contact is that the contact force can be carefully controlled to the level of nanonewtons (~a billionth of a pound), so that the metal does not punch through the molecular film creating an electrical short. Also, the radius of the top contact is small such that it touches only 50-100 parallel molecules in the film.

 Using this geometry, measurements of electrical resistance were made as a function of molecular length and the backbone architecture. The results showed that the resistance increases very steeply (exponentially) with length for wires 1-4 nm in length, and then increases more slowly (linearly) for wires longer than 4 nm.  Temperature dependent measurements also showed that for the short wires the resistance was not sensitive to temperature, whereas for long wires the resistance was very sensitive to temperature. These observations suggest a change in the conduction mechanism from quantum mechanical tunneling to more classical ohmic conduction as wire length increased. One large question that was not clear from the experiments was how to visualize the charges (electrons) on the backbone of the wires, i.e., were they localized to small segments of the wires or delocalized?  Here, the PI and his graduate students collaborated with computational chemists who calculated the ground state structures of the wires with an excess charge. The computation revealed that for the long molecules (> 4 nm) the charge was localized and distorted the molecule forming what is known as a ‘polaron’. The polarons hopped along the chain. The calculated hopping energy agreed very well with experiment and showed that the critical motion that allowed the polaron to hop was a torsion of the wire backbone. These experiments have motivated ongoing work to control and limit the torsional motion of the wires in order to make them better conductors.

Another important aspect of this project was the development of approaches to characterize the step-by-step wire synthesis using click chemistry. Understanding the structure of the wires with atomic detail was naturally important to interpretation of the conduction measurements. A variety of conventional surface characterization techniques were employed including spectroscopic ellipsometry, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and reflection-absorption infrared spectroscopy. In addition, two other ion beam analysis methods were used to characterize composition of the wires, namely Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS) and nuclear reaction analysis (NRA). RBS measured the sulfur and iron concentration in the wires and allowed determination of the areal density of the wires (number of wires per nm2). The NRA measured carbon concentration after each click chemistry step; from the increase in carbon per step the reaction yield was determined to be over 99% per step.
